awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Elucidating the basis of retrotransposon target preference
awd_abstract_narration:
Transposition mechanisms of Penelope-like elements are one of the last uncharacterized mechanism of retromobility in eukaryotes. Establishment of a tractable system to dissect the mechanism and target preferences of these elements would not only advance our basic understanding of naturally occurring genome rearrangements but may also help design novel gene delivery systems in eukaryotes. The project will provide support for a summer undergraduate internship to train a student in microbiology and molecular biology techniques in the context of intensive summer research atmosphere at the MBL.

Retrotransposons are mobile genetic elements, i.e., fragments of DNA that are inserted in the genomes of multicellular organisms, but may replicate autonomously, using virus-like mechanisms of making RNA and then reverse transcribing it. The two main retrotransposon subclasse are the LTR-and non-LTR (LINE) retrotransposons and the third major subclass, named Penelope-like elements has been found only recently and is not well-studied. Interestingly, and unlike the other two classes of retrotransposons, Penelope-like elements appear to locate in those regions of the genome where the nucleotide sequence is arranged into the so-called (TA)n microsatellites, i.e., multiple repetitions of just two nucleotides. Such repetitions are rarely found within active protein-coding genes, and in this project, researchers are seeking to define the molecular details of how the retroelements 'find' where to integrate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Reverse transcriptases (RTs) are unorthodox enzymes which can make DNA copies of RNA transcripts, which is the direction opposite to what occurs routinely in living cells. The process of reverse transcription is used primarily by mobile genetic elements, such as retrotransposons and retroviruses, to convert their RNA into DNA, so that it could be integrated into new locations in the genome of the host cell. Retrotransposon-encoded RTs can generate multiple copies of their cognate RNAs to ensure their spread within and between genomes. Eukaryotic RTs are divided into three different types, corresponding to retroelements encoding them: retroviruses/LTR-retrotransposons, non-LTR retrotransposons, and Penelope-like elements (PLEs). Each type is associated with a specific endonuclease domain that can cut genomic DNA, making possible the insertion of a new copy. Recently, the properties of retrotransposons to make DNA copies from RNA have been exploited to create new genome editing tools, taking advantage of the ease of RNA delivery to the host cells and the detailed knowledge of the requirements for the retrotransposition process. The insertion specificity of non-LTR retrotransposons, however, is mostly restricted to ribosomal DNA target sequences, which are multicopy but are inactivated by insertion of additional DNA. It is important to expand the diversity of specific targets, which may lower the risk of disrupting functional genes. We have identified subsets of PLEs that insert into dinucleotide microsatellites, which are unlikely to occur in coding sequences. The project provided essential information about the requirements for PLE reverse transcription, identifying the cis-acting elements that allow RT to reverse-transcribe the corresponding RNAs, and the prerequisites for target cleavage. This knowledge can be used to design two-component systems, consisting of the RNA encoding the functional RT enzyme and the RNA on which this enzyme can act. The results serve as the stepping stone towards the comprehensive model of PLE retrotransposition, which is still under-developed for this type of retroelements, and provide the basis for design of novel genetic tools based on retroelement ability to serve as gene delivery vehicles.

Broader impacts: The project provided training for three summer interns: an undergraduate, a high school senior, and a master’s degree candidate. This experience not only expanded their horizons by direct involvement into cutting-edge research and the opportunity to attend on-campus seminars and lectures by visiting scientists from all over the world, but also helped them in their job searches and college admissions. The results were disseminated to the broader scientific community at one international and two national meetings and at an invited seminar at a minority-serving institution. We published an original research article based on the project findings, and two review articles on reverse transcriptases serving as a comprehensive source of information on this topic.
